articles.headline: Negligence Is Debated in Jackson Death Case
articles.snippet: The civil trial over Michael Jackson’s death might hinge on whether reasonable care was exercised in the hiring of his doctor.
articles.abstract: The civil trial over Michael Jackson’s death might hinge on whether reasonable care was exercised in the hiring of his doctor.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After only two weeks of testimony, no side has a clear advantage in the civil trial pitting the mother of Michael Jackson against A.E.G. Live, the promoter of his attempted comeback concerts, over the question of who was responsible for Jackson’s death.

articles.headline: As Firms Line Up on Factories, Wal-Mart Plans Solo Effort
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart, rejecting a safety plan backed by more than a dozen European companies, said its monitors would “conduct in-depth safety inspections” at all factories it uses in Bangladesh.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart, rejecting a safety plan backed by more than a dozen European companies, said its monitors would “conduct in-depth safety inspections” at all factories it uses in Bangladesh.
articles.lead_paragraph: As American retailers face mounting pressure to join a landmark plan to improve factory safety in Bangladesh, newly found documents indicate that apparel had been produced for Wal-Mart at one of the operations in the factory building that collapsed last month, killing more than 1,100 workers.

articles.headline: U.S. Budget Deficit Shrinks Far Faster Than Expected
articles.snippet: The Congressional Budget Office said the 2013 fiscal deficit would fall to about $642 billion, or 4 percent of G.D.P., about $200 billion less than it estimated just three months ago.
articles.abstract: The Congressional Budget Office said the 2013 fiscal deficit would fall to about $642 billion, or 4 percent of G.D.P., about $200 billion less than it estimated just three months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since the recession ended four years ago, the federal budget deficit has topped $1 trillion every year. But now the government’s annual deficit is shrinking far faster than anyone in Washington expected, and perhaps even faster than many economists think is advisable for the health of the economy.

articles.headline: Management Flaws at I.R.S. Cited in Tea Party Scrutiny
articles.snippet: An inspector general’s report described a failure to stop the singling out of conservative groups as Congressional aides tried to find out how far knowledge of the effort reached.
articles.abstract: An inspector general’s report described a failure to stop the singling out of conservative groups as Congressional aides tried to find out how far knowledge of the effort reached.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An inspector general’s report issued Tuesday blamed ineffective Internal Revenue Service management in the failure to stop employees from singling out conservative groups for added scrutiny. Congressional aides, meanwhile, sought to determine whether the Obama administration’s knowledge of the effort extended beyond the I.R.S.

articles.headline: Subscribers Fear Bloomberg Is Becoming Their Rival
articles.snippet: Long thought of as a company that serves Wall Street firms, Bloomberg L.P. is quietly becoming more like them.
articles.abstract: Long thought of as a company that serves Wall Street firms, Bloomberg L.P. is quietly becoming more like them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long thought of as a company that serves the needs of Wall Street firms, Bloomberg L.P. is quietly becoming more like them, moving recently into businesses that have been the domain of the largest banks.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: An Atrocity in Syria, With No Victim Too Small
articles.snippet: A mass killing has revealed new depths of ruthlessness in Syria’s conflict, inflaming sectarian divisions and making any hope of reconciliation appear ever more distant.
articles.abstract: A mass killing has revealed new depths of ruthlessness in Syria’s conflict, inflaming sectarian divisions and making any hope of reconciliation appear ever more distant.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — After dragging 46 bodies from the streets near his hometown on the Syrian coast, Omar lost count. For four days, he said, he could not eat, remembering the burned body of a baby just a few months old; a fetus ripped from a woman’s belly; a friend lying dead, his dog still standing guard.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Hania Mourtada

articles.headline: For Insurers, No Doubts on Climate Change
articles.snippet: A new institute, financed by the insurance industry, not only believes in global warming but also supports a carbon tax to combat it.
articles.abstract: A new institute, financed by the insurance industry, not only believes in global warming but also supports a carbon tax to combat it.
articles.lead_paragraph: If there were one American industry that would be particularly worried about climate change it would have to be insurance, right?

articles.headline: How They Do It Elsewhere
articles.snippet: Scores of other countries have elaborate retirement schemes and policies that Americans could learn from to address some of the biggest pitfalls of their system.
articles.abstract: Scores of other countries have elaborate retirement schemes and policies that Americans could learn from to address some of the biggest pitfalls of their system.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE United States can boast that it has the world’s best basketball players, fighter jets and country and western singers. But hardly anyone would ever boast that the United States has the world’s best retirement system.

articles.headline: Filling Up an Empty Nest
articles.snippet: Some older parents never got their fill of child-rearing; others never had children and finally have the time and means to try raising some.
articles.abstract: Some older parents never got their fill of child-rearing; others never had children and finally have the time and means to try raising some.
articles.lead_paragraph: RETIRING from work? Then it might be time to think about raising a family. Some brave older adults are turning the idea of retirement on its head by choosing to adopt children — this when many of their peers are traveling, socializing, taking up intellectual or entrepreneurial pursuits, or just plain relaxing.

articles.headline: In Role Reversal, Goldman Chief Advises Dimon
articles.snippet: It is now Jamie Dimon, not Lloyd Blankfein, who is caught in a harsh public spotlight, seemingly at odds with regulators.
articles.abstract: It is now Jamie Dimon, not Lloyd Blankfein, who is caught in a harsh public spotlight, seemingly at odds with regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon has consulted lawyers, public relation experts and bankers as JPMorgan Chase wrestles with the fallout from a multibillion-dollar trading loss. But the bank chief has received advice from an unexpected corner: Lloyd C. Blankfein of rival Goldman Sachs.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Uninvited Guest Gives Japan’s Business Culture a Jolt
articles.snippet: Japan has traditionally been hostile to Western investors. How the country and Sony react to demands from Daniel S. Loeb could test Japan’s commitment to welcoming foreign investment and, more important, economic change.
articles.abstract: Japan has traditionally been hostile to Western investors. How the country and Sony react to demands from Daniel S. Loeb could test Japan’s commitment to welcoming foreign investment and, more important, economic change.

articles.headline: U.S. Now Paints Apple as ‘Ringmaster’ in Its Lawsuit on E-Book Price-Fixing
articles.snippet: According to the Justice Department, Apple took a leadership role in a price-fixing conspiracy in the market for e-books.
articles.abstract: According to the Justice Department, Apple took a leadership role in a price-fixing conspiracy in the market for e-books.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The e-mail, from Steve Jobs of Apple to James Murdoch of News Corporation, reads as if one old sport were trying to cajole another into joining a caper: “Throw in with Apple and see if we can all make a go of this to create a real mainstream e-books market at $12.99 and $14.99.”
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Two Musical Minds Seek a Different Kind of Mogul
articles.snippet: The music business partners Jimmy Iovine and Dr. Dre gave $70 million to the University of Southern California to start an academic program for the development of creative entrepreneurs.
articles.abstract: The music business partners Jimmy Iovine and Dr. Dre gave $70 million to the University of Southern California to start an academic program for the development of creative entrepreneurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The record producer Jimmy Iovine and his business partner Dr. Dre have a keen eye for talent. Between them, the two have jump-started the careers of stars ranging from Lady Gaga to 50 Cent to the Black Eyed Peas.

articles.headline: Euro Zone Politics Hinder Response as Slump Persists
articles.snippet: Data released Wednesday showed France slipping into recession and Germany eking out weak growth, but analysts said any new plans to stimulate growth remained unlikely.
articles.abstract: Data released Wednesday showed France slipping into recession and Germany eking out weak growth, but analysts said any new plans to stimulate growth remained unlikely.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Europe slipped deeper into a widespread recession, according to data released Wednesday. But when European heads of state meet next week in Brussels, no big announcements about plans to stimulate growth are expected.
